title: 114_s1550
content:
The Act titled "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" establishes governmentwide standards for program and project management. The Deputy Director for Management is responsible for overseeing the implementation of these standards and chairing the Program Management Policy Council. The Deputy Director for Management is responsible for overseeing the implementation of program and project management standards, policies, and guidelines for executive agencies. This includes chairing the Program Management Policy Council, establishing standards and policies, engaging with the private sector for best practices, conducting portfolio reviews for high-risk programs, and conducting annual portfolio reviews. The Deputy Director for Management oversees the implementation of program and project management standards, policies, and guidelines for executive agencies. This includes conducting portfolio reviews for high-risk programs, coordinating with Project Management Improvement Officers for program assessment, and establishing a 5-year strategic plan for program and project management. The provisions do not apply to the Department of Defense if substantially similar to chapter 87 of title 10. The Deputy Director for Management will establish a 5-year strategic plan for program and project management. The Department of Defense is exempt if similar provisions exist in chapter 87 of title 10 or in their policy. The Deputy Director must issue the required standards, policies, and guidelines within one year of the Act's enactment. Regulations must be issued within 90 days. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget will issue standards, policies, and guidelines within 1 year of the Act's enactment. Regulations must be issued within 90 days to implement the requirements of section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will issue regulations to implement section 503(c) of title 31, United States Code. Chapter 11 of title 31 is amended to include Program Management Improvement Officers and Program Management Policy Council. Each agency must designate a senior executive as the Program Management Improvement Officer. The head of each agency must designate a senior executive as the Program Management Improvement Officer. This officer will implement program management policies and develop strategies to enhance the role of program managers within the agency, including providing enhanced training opportunities. The Program Management Improvement Officer must provide training in relevant competencies for program and project managers in the private sector, focusing on cost containment for large projects and programs. The Program Management Improvement Officer aims to mentor current and future program managers, improve career paths, recruit highly qualified individuals, share best practices, and provide tools for data analysis. This does not apply to the Department of Defense if similar provisions are already in place. The Program Management Improvement Officer mentors program managers, improves career paths, recruits qualified individuals, shares best practices, and provides data analysis tools. A Program Management Policy Council is established in the Office of Management and Budget. The Program Management Improvement Officer is established as the principal interagency forum for improving agency practices related to program and project management. The Council advises the Deputy Director for Management, reviews high-risk programs, and discusses important topics for the workforce. The Program Management Improvement Officer advises the Deputy Director for Management on high-risk programs, workforce development needs, program management standards, and information transparency. The Program Management Improvement Officer advises on challenges in managing programs, develops governmentwide standards for program management transparency, and reviews information on the Office of Management and Budget website. The Deputy Director for Management, Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government, Administrator of Federal Procurement Policy, Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management, and Director of the Office of Performance and Personnel Management are key positions within the government. The Council includes the Program Management Improvement Officer from each agency, designated officers or employees of the Federal Government, and the Chairperson who is the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget. The Chairperson presides over meetings, sets the agenda, directs the work of the Council, and establishes subgroups as needed. The Chairperson of the Council, elected by members, serves a term of up to 1 year and presides over meetings, sets agendas, directs work, and establishes subgroups. The Council must meet at least twice per fiscal year and agencies with a Project Management Improvement Officer must provide administrative support upon request. The Management Improvement Officer supports the Council as requested by the Chairperson. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must submit a report to Congress within a year. Program and Project Management Personnel Standards require regulations to be issued within 180 days. The Program and Project Management Personnel Standards mandate the Director of the Office of Personnel Management to issue regulations within 180 days, defining key skills and competencies for program and project managers in agencies. This includes creating a new job series or enhancing an existing one for program and project management within agencies. The Office of Personnel Management must issue regulations defining key skills and competencies for program and project managers in agencies, establish new job series or enhance existing ones, and create a new career path for managers. The Government Accountability Office will assess the effectiveness of policies on improving Federal program and project management within three years. The Government Accountability Office will issue a report examining the effectiveness of standards, policies, and guidelines for program and project management, the 5-year strategic plan, Program Management Improvement Officers, and the Program Management Policy Council in improving Federal program and project management.
